In the finiÅ¿hing of their worke of rowing and Å¿hearing they will vÅ¿e a deceit with flox of the Å¿ame colour of the cloth, which they can Å¿heare as Å¿mall as duÅ¿t, which mixt with Å¿olace, they Å¿pread vpon the muÅ¿ters, and where the cloth may bee Å¿eene, which makes it Å¿eeme much finer than it is, and feele more Å¿ubÅ¿tantiall in hand; but the Å¿ame cloth lying a while after the dreÅ¿Å¿ing, the Å¿olace drieth vp, and then the Å¿ame flox flyeth away leaning the cloth in his owne nature againe.

Colours. For the falÅ¿e dying of colors both in woolls, cloth, and Å¿tuffes, with the vÅ¿e of logwood, it is intollerarable, and too common, to the great diÅ¿credit of the thing Å¿o died. The ground of good colours is Å¿ubÅ¿tantiall woading, without which diuers colors cannot be perfectly made, as blackes, ruÅ¿Å¿ets, tawnyes, purples, greenes, and Å¿uch like, wherof many of them are made without foundation of woad, it appeareth beautifull and pleaÅ¿ing to the eye, but in vÅ¿e and wearing proue like falÅ¿e painting and not true dying: Some colours haue a Å¿light ground of woad, but farre too weake for the depth of that colour it beares, yet can Å¿et vp the woade marke, or woade roÅ¿e, which is vpon the piece at a farre richer depth than the peice is woaded throughout: nay farther, Å¿ome can Å¿et on a woadmarke vpon a cloth with a little Indico which hath no woade at all on the peice: but herein the diers of London doe beÅ¿t obÅ¿erue a true courÅ¿e in Å¿etting a woaded Å¿eale vpon woaded colours, which is a truer teÅ¿timonie than the woade roÅ¿e or marke Å¿o many waies abuÅ¿ed, yet is not the vÅ¿e of that Å¿eale effectually performed in this kind. There is fiue eÅ¿peciall degrees in woading that is to Å¿ay a huling, a plounket, a watchet, anazur, & a blew, euery one of theÅ¿e exceeding each other in value, yet euery one of them fit for Å¿ome colours: Now if theÅ¿e degrees were truely expreÅ¿Å¿ed on the woaded Å¿eale, then might the buyer knowe the trueth of each colour, and cauÅ¿e a reformation of that intollerable abuÅ¿e, which doth daily cauÅ¿e Å¿uch numbers
of our cloths and Å¿tuffes, to bee caried out of the realme to bee dreÅ¿Å¿ed and died, to the great preiudice of many of the Kings maieÅ¿ties Å¿ubiects which might be wel maintained vpon thoÅ¿e imployments: the trueth of the colour is as materiall as the goodneÅ¿Å¿e of the cloth, for as oftentimes good cloth is Å¿poyled by a bad colour, Å¿o doth a good colour often mend and preferre a meane cloth, therefore as needefull to bee prouided for Å¿ome:CaÅ¿uall faults. faults come by negligence without deceiuable intent, as Å¿ometime by ouermilling of a cloth through abÅ¿ence of the mill-man, then is there Å¿ome Å¿orts of woolles of that nature as will not proue Å¿o well in milling as other woolles: Å¿ometime a cloth ouer heated with going too drie in the mill and Å¿o conÅ¿umed, Å¿ometime a Å¿mall Å¿tone in the fulling earth workes many brackes or holles in the cloth, then may miÅ¿fortune happen by bad oyles, as Whale oyle by lying long will chaunge the colour and alter the cloth; Å¿ometime a cloth hurt by roukling to the mill, which fault might bee well put in the milmans deceit, becauÅ¿e hee doth the Å¿ame with cards to rake off much flox.

Againe the want of the clothiers marke may Å¿ometimes come by negligence of the weauer, but often pretended wilfully, either in regard of the falÅ¿hood of the Cloth which makes them Å¿hame to Å¿et their marke, or els intending to put another mans marke in it, which they commonly doe without weauing, Å¿owing the Å¿ame being taw, and Å¿o
milled vpon it: but verie fit it is that euerie marke Å¿hould bee wouen in the cloth, to draw them to perfect making, for the credit of their markes.

Deceits vÅ¿ed by Å¿ome merchants and drapers. Some of theÅ¿e merchants doe buy Å¿light Å¿ayes and put them forth to milling, and make baÅ¿tard perpetuanas of them good to the Å¿ight, but Å¿o vnprofitable in wearing, that the Å¿ame abuÅ¿es doe vtterly diÅ¿credit that commoditie.

A Å¿ort of cloth is made called MancheÅ¿ter or LancaÅ¿hire plaines to make cottons, which containe about a yard in breadth: theÅ¿e are often bought by merchants and others, which cut them in length according to a kerÅ¿ie, and hath them dreÅ¿Å¿ed and dyed in forme to a kerÅ¿ie, the which are not onely vented into forein parts, but many of them vented in the Realme; which cloth proues verie vnprofitable in wearing. AlÅ¿o there haue Å¿ome merchants cauÅ¿ed counterfeit DeuonÅ¿hire kerÅ¿ies to bee made in YorkÅ¿hire out of waÅ¿hers or halfethicks, which haue contained Å¿uch length and breadth with Å¿top liÅ¿ts, like thoÅ¿e DeuonÅ¿hire kerÅ¿ies, which they haue cauÅ¿ed to be dreÅ¿Å¿ed, died, & preÅ¿Å¿ed with the hot preÅ¿Å¿e,

Some Drapers haue made practiÅ¿e to draw the forell of a fine KentiÅ¿h Cloth vpon a Northen Dozen, Å¿o cunningly as could not eaÅ¿ily be perceiued, which forell by the Alnegers negligence hath had the kings armes with the name of that countie vpon it, whereas he ought to Å¿et it within the Cloth. The Å¿ent of thoÅ¿e Northen Dozens hath been taken away, firÅ¿t by ayring, and afterwards with liquors or powders: Å¿o the buyers haue not had onely the forels to deceiue them, but in falÅ¿e manner, the kings Å¿eale hath beene made vÅ¿e of to that purpoÅ¿e: and then the deceiuer to conclude all, layes his hand vpon the forell, and with an equinocating oath, Å¿weares this KentiÅ¿h cloth coÅ¿t him Å¿o much.

There is alÅ¿o a late commoditie in great vÅ¿e of making within this kingdome,FuÅ¿tians. which Å¿etteth many people on worke, called FuÅ¿tians, which for want of gouernement are Å¿o decayed by falÅ¿hood, keeping neither order in goodneÅ¿Å¿e nor aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e, inÅ¿omuch that the makers thereof, in this Å¿hort time of vÅ¿e, are wearie

TheÅ¿e many enormities are now in the hight of practiÅ¿e, the euill diÅ¿poÅ¿ed hauing no feeling thereof, but runne forward to the ruine of all: but to the well diÅ¿poÅ¿ed which lookes into theÅ¿e abufes, it appeares lamentable and grieuous, deÅ¿iring that a better portion may be procured for thoÅ¿e offenders, to purge Å¿o vile and dangerous a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, which may in Å¿hort time grow incurable.

div.head: CHAP. 6. The inconuenience and hurt by theÅ¿e abuÅ¿es.
div.p:
WHileÅ¿t the true making of Cloth indured in reaÅ¿onable maner it was moÅ¿t vendible in al parts, & Å¿o much deÅ¿ired, that foreine Merchants did vÅ¿ually come into this realme, to fetch them away: but Å¿ince deceit crept in, he hath grown greater, and increaÅ¿ed euery day, the trade Å¿till declining from bad to worÅ¿e, and now to worÅ¿t of all, like Iuie, which being Å¿uffered, claÅ¿peth the tree Å¿o hard, that in time the bodie dies thereby. What maketh thoÅ¿e now to refuÅ¿e our Cloth being brought to their owne dores, which before time earneÅ¿tly Å¿ought it at ours? falÅ¿hood. What makes the Gentleman complaine of his Wooll which lyes on his hand? The clothier complaine of his dead Å¿ales? The Merchant complaine on his loÅ¿Å¿e? all but falÅ¿hood. What will this come vnto? Nay what is it come to alreadie? The Authors of this euill, both the bad Clothier & the bad merchant, are Å¿urfeited with their Å¿weet meat, like Prodigals that Å¿pend their patrimony in a momeÌt, which might wel Å¿erue them & their poÅ¿terity: deceits caÌnot indure, eÅ¿pecially whoÌ that it growes violent, nor can they throw it Å¿o far off, but that it will rebound back to them which threw it.

How thicke are certificats of falÅ¿hood returned vpon our Merchants from beyond the Å¿eas? Å¿o that they know no end of their trouble, nor certaine of their gaine or loÅ¿Å¿e vntill their moneys be receiued, and abatements deducted. Bad wares are the breeders of bad debts and deÅ¿perat hazards, wherewith both Merchaunts and makers are extreamely puniÅ¿ht: when a complement of defectiue cloth is made, the owner is often inforced to barter for as bad a commoditie, a hilding for a Iade, or elÅ¿e to deliuer it out with a handfull of that Å¿weet hearbe time, but receiue it with a backe burden of the bitter hearbe Rew. So heere is aduenture increaÅ¿ed, in which point the Merchant far exceeds the makerâª Yet the maker is an aduenturer, who hath his goods and Å¿ubÅ¿tance diÅ¿perÅ¿ed into many hands, yea and amongÅ¿t the poorer Å¿ort, of diuers conditions, whoÅ¿e fingers are like thornie buÅ¿hes which the Å¿heep muÅ¿t go through, in euerie of which, do what he can, he Å¿hall leaue a locke of his fleece behind him, and although he preÅ¿erue the principall, yet will a part be detained indirectly: Then when he hath with great care and time finiÅ¿ht his worke, he muÅ¿t vndergoe a doubtful Market, and often light on a bad marchant, which defeats him of all: yet herein is his comfort; for his worke folke, they are within the compaÅ¿Å¿e of his view, and Å¿eldome faile, by reaÅ¿on of their continual dependaÌce; for his Markets he doth weekely know his worÅ¿t; and for his Merchant, he may daily Å¿ee or beare from him at the Royal-Exchange,
if his dealing be in London, & in other places within the Realme in like manner. Wherefore, his frazards are but petie aduentures in regard of the Merchants.

For when thoÅ¿e commodities are faÅ¿tned on the merchant, he muÅ¿t indure a number of dangerous aduentures, both outward and inward, Å¿hipwracks at Sea, peril of Pirats, and other robbers; at his place of Å¿ale, there he muÅ¿t giue credit to thoÅ¿e hee neuer Å¿aw, and Å¿uch as neither liue in his religion nor Law, he muÅ¿t abide to anÅ¿wer all defects found, where our owne Laws Å¿halbe alledged to puniÅ¿h them who before was not priuie to the offence. If they eÅ¿cape confiÅ¿cation, yet Å¿hall they be Å¿ure of intollerable abatements, with bad words, and Å¿hamefull reproches; they muÅ¿t Å¿tand to the honeÅ¿ty of their factors, which often proue falÅ¿e, and the daunger of the Countrie often Å¿ubject to change. TheÅ¿e and many other caÅ¿ualties cauÅ¿eth cares to abridge his reÅ¿t, and keepes him waking when others Å¿leepe, euerie Å¿tormie wind breedes his feare, and euerie flying report makes him doubtfull, and not without great cauÅ¿e, Å¿eeing Å¿o many fall Å¿o lainly to the vtter ouerthrow, not onely of themÅ¿elues, but diuers other depending vpon them, like to the fall of a mightie Tree, which cruÅ¿heth downe the vnder Å¿hrubs about him, Å¿o farre as his fall did reach. Therefore the chiefe remedie to preuent much of this miÅ¿chiefe, is to deale in loyall and perfect commodities, which will with credit abide his time for Market, when the other by long
lying looÅ¿eth Å¿till, both in goodnes and credit; procuring haÅ¿tie bargains, that brings after repentance. In Prouinces beyond the bounds of ChriÅ¿tendome, God is blaÅ¿phemed, our Religion reuiled, and our people miÅ¿tearmed in beaÅ¿tly manner: when a Turke or Infidell bruÅ¿heth his garment bare, that he may number the threeds, and find it to haue feeling fence to runne in at a wet Å¿howre, or a hot Iron, then our ChriÅ¿tian profeÅ¿Å¿ion is called in queÅ¿tion by thoÅ¿e prophane people, who meaÅ¿ure our faith by our works. In kingdomes nere vs, theÅ¿e abuÅ¿es haue been found Å¿o odious, and their people Å¿o much wronged, that they haue made lawes and edicts, to baniÅ¿h our cloth out of their couÌtries, rather deÅ¿iring our wools, wherewith they can make true commodities. This hath Å¿et diuers couÌtries on work, in making of cloth, which Å¿erueth thoÅ¿e places of traffike, where we did vÅ¿e to commerce, diuers workemen haue gone out of this Land, to make vÅ¿e of their practiÅ¿e and liuing there, where they are intertained, and daily increaÅ¿e: In our owne Countrie, where much of our Wooll may bee vented, the falÅ¿hood of clothing is Å¿o common, that euerie one Å¿triueth to weare any thing rather than cloth: if a gentleman make a liuerie for his man, in the firÅ¿t Å¿howre of raine it may fit his Page for bigneÅ¿Å¿e, and for the colours and other conditions in it, after a moneths wearing, it will looke like a Å¿ouldiers coat which hath line Å¿ixe moneths out of garriÅ¿on. It hath bin knowne that a poore man, getting Å¿o much money together with care and trauell
as would buy him a Å¿uit of cloth, and taking his Taylor with him, who Å¿eeing the cloth, hath juÅ¿tly told him how much would Å¿erue to make his Ierkin, and breeches which he hath bought accordingly, afterwards counceld by that Taylor, to caÅ¿t his Cloth in the water, to make it more Å¿eruiceable, which he Å¿o doing, hath quite loÅ¿t his Ierkin, and hauing no more money, was forced to goe cold all winter in his vpper parts: this in Å¿ome degree may be accounted Å¿acriledge, to rob the poore; what are the inconueniences that are drawne on by theÅ¿e meanes? firÅ¿t, indignitie to our king, whoÅ¿e Å¿eale is fixt on this cloth, iniurie to our nation that workes abuÅ¿e on this cloth, infamie to our Å¿elues that weare Å¿ome part of this Cloth, and vtter ruine of all benefits which Å¿hould ariÅ¿e by this cloth. It is high time to looke out, when the fire hath caught hold of the houÅ¿e end; if it be not preuented by quenching it will Å¿oone conÅ¿ume to the ground, and it is doubtfull whether theÅ¿e enormities are incurable or no: the plant of falÅ¿hood is grown Å¿o great and antient, that it may be Å¿uppoÅ¿ed rather to breake than bend, but extraordinarie means and paines muÅ¿t be applied to the cauÅ¿e, which may be recouered by good induÅ¿trie.

div.head: CHAP. VII. The remedie to be made by the Alnegers prouiÅ¿ion.
div.p:
AS this full growne euill hath now procured a daungerous hurt, Å¿o hath it verie happily falne out in a time which can afford an eÅ¿peciall remedie. When this kingdome was diuided amongÅ¿t Å¿euen kings, it was vnder a Å¿trange gouernement: when there was twiÅ¿e Å¿euen Alnegers in the realme, there was neither law nor order obÅ¿erued amongÅ¿t theÌ; but all they Å¿ought was gaine, and how to intrude into each others benefit: if a Clothier or offender were interrupted in his falÅ¿hood within one Countie, he could freely exerciÅ¿e the Å¿ame in another; where he Å¿hould be willingly receiued, becauÅ¿e he augmented that Alnegers profit. But now, thankes be to God, wee liue vnder one gratious Prince, who ordaines no diuerÅ¿itie of Lawes; but hath prouided one order of gouernement for all; So that ill diuided office of Alnage which ran to ruine in many hands, is now reduced into one worthie mans hands; which hath not only power to command, but alÅ¿o will to performe all meanes, and courÅ¿es, which may tend to the reformation of this grieuous enormitie: In this buÅ¿ines
many hands muÅ¿t bee imployed, whoÅ¿e worke may Å¿eeme harÅ¿h to thoÅ¿e which Å¿hall be put out of their wonted courÅ¿e: But it is not their content that is Å¿ought; vnto a generall good euerie perticular help muÅ¿t bee applied, heere muÅ¿t bee more paines in the Alneger, more care and truth in the workman, and more trouble to the clothier, but all to a good and profitable end. The firÅ¿t thing to bee looked vnto, is the condition of the clothiers and makers of cloth, Å¿tuffes, and commodities belonging to this gouernment, which at this time is much differing from law or order, many of them vnexperienced and vÅ¿urpers of the trade, who not being maÅ¿ters thereof through want of knowledge commit moÅ¿t of theÅ¿e abuÅ¿es. And whereas the law prouides that none which profeÅ¿Å¿e thoÅ¿e trades Å¿hould bee admitted vnder Å¿euen yeares Å¿eruice in apprentiÅ¿hip, diuers do come into the Å¿ame with a moneths practize, and cloies the Kingdome with defectiue commodities, beggering themÅ¿elues, and hurting thoÅ¿e which Å¿hould liue by the Å¿ame: TheÅ¿e people for the moÅ¿t part dwelling in obÅ¿cure places, neuer bringing their commodities to Å¿earch or Å¿eale, nor yeelding any duetie, liue rather like outlawes than Å¿ubiects. There is a petition vnto the Kings MaieÅ¿tie, extant from the beÅ¿t clothiers and makers in diuers parts to this purpoÅ¿e, who craue a corporation for the amendment of this, which were pittie but it Å¿hould be graunted, confidering how many inferiour trades enioies Å¿uch priuiledge that gouerne their companies
in good Å¿ort and order. If this were accompliÅ¿hed, the better halfe of this great taske were finiÅ¿hed, and great hope that our generall Alneger will procure it, beeing Å¿o good an aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance to worke the reformation which lies on his charge.

The diÅ¿perÅ¿ing of clothiers and makers is a principall cauÅ¿e to breed theÅ¿e defects: whereas the lawe ordaines that clothing Å¿hall not bee vÅ¿ed but in a citie, borough, or market towne, or elÅ¿e where clothing hath beene vÅ¿ually, to the end that the eye of the officer Å¿hould bee vpon their doings: Now they Å¿catter themÅ¿elues in vnfitting places, and if there bee but one clothier in a pariÅ¿h hee will demaund an Alneger to attend him, if not, force the Alneger to come vnto his houÅ¿e to Å¿eale his cloth, where hee Å¿hall beÅ¿towe twelue peny worth of labour for the earning or receiuing of one groate: and when hee comes thither hee Å¿hall find them Å¿earched by his neighbours that hee hath cauÅ¿ed to bee choÅ¿en Å¿earchers, who haue no skil, or elÅ¿e by his workman who dare doe nothing but what himÅ¿elfe directeth, and if the Alneger will Å¿ometime call their Å¿earch in queÅ¿tion and trie the cloth, hee Å¿hall neither haue place conuenient to view them, nor weights of any certaintie to weigh them, but Å¿uch weights as they will bring him, which Å¿hall bee Å¿tones, logges, and Å¿uch other things as they will tell him their weight, and hee muÅ¿t beleeue them. There is
no officer vnder the king Å¿o much deluded & abuÅ¿ed as hee, beeing Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿arie for the kingdome and beneficiall to the crowne: Somtime, and in Å¿ome places they will call him from his reÅ¿t at all houres of the night to performe his office, not for neceÅ¿Å¿itie, but of purpoÅ¿e to diÅ¿turbe him, with many other iniuries, which they in baÅ¿e manner haue offered him: but herein himÅ¿elfe is moÅ¿t to bee blamed, that knowing his owne power and place would Å¿uffer Å¿uch indignities. The courÅ¿e of theÅ¿e dayes is for Å¿uch as will beare to haue greater burdens put vpon them than can bee borne. It is vnknowne that any officer of the Kings which hath the keeping and vÅ¿e of his Å¿eale Å¿hould bee Å¿ubiect to Å¿uch Å¿eruitude, neither is it conuenient: therefore the true courÅ¿e herein to bee obÅ¿etued, is for the Alneger, to prouide in euerie place (needfull for an Alnegers reÅ¿idence) a conuenient roome for all Makers or Clothiers to come vnto, wherein muÅ¿t bee a pearch to drawe ouer the clothes, a table to meaÅ¿ure and trie the clothes, and a beame with true weights to weigh the clothes, and the deputie not onely to bee Å¿ufficient in abilitie and knowledge but alÅ¿o bound, and Å¿worne to performe his office truely, that hee Å¿hall bee there alwaies readie at conuenient or appointed times to make a true Å¿earch in all points, and in no place elÅ¿where, and vpon the altering of the propertie of the cloth, to make a new Å¿earch in theÅ¿e degrees:
FirÅ¿t, if the aforeÅ¿aid corporation bee procured, that then the clothes bee firÅ¿t viewed raw by the wardens or aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tants of that corporation, to Å¿ee whether the cloth bee made of Å¿ound yarne, or any deceit bee wrought by the weauer, and beeing found merchantable to bee marked at the head end with a marke of allowance cut in the cloth according to the manner of Å¿earch now vÅ¿ed vpon raw DeuonÅ¿hire kerfies, but beeing defectiue either to iagge the Å¿ame at both ends, or cut off the head forrell from the cloth, and to Å¿et Å¿uch fine vpon the offendor as thoÅ¿e Wardens or OuerÅ¿eers Å¿hall find the fault deÅ¿erue. But for the Alnegers charge, when the cloth is thicked from the mill to meaÅ¿ure the Å¿ame truely in length and breadth, not truÅ¿ting to the clothiers content who will often for the credit of his cloth, Å¿et on more length than it doth truely containe; and that the Alneger doth Å¿et on the iuÅ¿t content in the water, whatÅ¿oeuer it contayneth on his Å¿eale, alÅ¿o expreÅ¿Å¿ing the the narrowneÅ¿Å¿e or other defects which hee Å¿hall find: And againÅ¿t euerie fault in the cloth to cut downe a notch of an inch deepe and therein fixe a Å¿eale as may appeare to the buyer where the fault is, then when this cloth is fully dried, that hee Å¿et one the iuÅ¿t content of weight alÅ¿o whatÅ¿oeuer it Å¿hall weigh, all this to bee done before the kings Å¿eale bee fixed thereunto.

When any of thoÅ¿e clothes are farther altered by dying, dreÅ¿Å¿ing, or Å¿trayning, that hee cauÅ¿e
thoÅ¿e former Å¿eales of the water to remaine Å¿till vpon the cloth, to expreÅ¿Å¿e what it was, and to Å¿et other Å¿eales vpon that cloth to Å¿hew vnto the buyer what that cloth is Å¿trained vnto according to the appointment of the Lords of his MaieÅ¿ties councell which graunted a tolleration for certaine clothes to bee Å¿trained, yet laid that charge vpon the Alneger, that the difference betweene the water content and Å¿trained length might bee Å¿eene: If other faults bee in that cloth either by dying or dreÅ¿Å¿ing, that the Å¿ame bee alÅ¿o notified by Å¿euerall Å¿eales: whether that cloth be colour graine, woaded, or contrarie in falÅ¿e color, Å¿o that in of right it ought to haue thoÅ¿e Å¿eales ollowing.
